title: End-of-Year Spiral Review & Mastery
description: Comprehensive spiral review across all 8th grade standards: 8.NS (Number System), 8.EE (Expressions & Equations), 8.F (Functions), 8.G (Geometry), and 8.SP (Statistics & Probability). Mixed-topic problem sets build fluency switching between concepts. Focus on multi-step problems requiring multiple skill integration and Algebra 1 readiness.
goals: Synthesize equation-solving, function analysis, and graphing skills across all problem types.
Apply geometric reasoning (transformations, Pythagorean theorem, volume) to multi-step problems.
Interpret data accurately and distinguish correlation from causation.
Demonstrate Algebra 1 readiness through fluent algebraic reasoning.
instructionalStrategy: AI-led diagnostic review targeting weakest areas first
Mixed-topic problem sets forcing students to choose the right tool for each problem
Multi-step problems requiring skills from multiple units
Error analysis tasks — find and fix common mistakes

scaffold.title: Review Block A: Number System & Equations (8.NS, 8.EE)
scaffold.content: Quick-reference review of the algebraic half of 8th grade.
keyPoints: Rational = a/b (terminates or repeats). Irrational = non-terminating, non-repeating (√2, π).
Exponent rules: aᵐ·aⁿ = aᵐ⁺ⁿ, aᵐ/aⁿ = aᵐ⁻ⁿ, (aᵐ)ⁿ = aᵐⁿ, a⁰ = 1, a⁻ⁿ = 1/aⁿ.
Scientific notation: a × 10ⁿ where 1 ≤ a < 10.
Multi-step equations: distribute, combine, isolate. Check EVERY answer.
Variables both sides: move all variables to one side, constants to the other.
Special cases: true statement = infinitely many; false statement = no solution.
Inequalities: flip the sign when multiplying/dividing by a negative.

scaffold.title: Review Block A: Mixed Number System & Equation Problems

problems.question: Simplify: (4⁻² · 4⁵) / 4²
hints: Add exponents in the numerator first, then subtract the denominator exponent.

problems.question: Solve: 4(2x − 3) = 5x + 6
hints: Distribute the 4 first, then collect variable terms on one side.

problems.question: The mass of a hydrogen atom is about 1.67 × 10⁻²⁴ grams. How much do 6 × 10²³ hydrogen atoms weigh?
problems.answer: (1.67 × 10⁻²⁴)(6 × 10²³) = 10.02 × 10⁻¹ = 1.002 grams ≈ 1 gram. (This is Avogadro's number — one mole of hydrogen!)
hints: Multiply the coefficients and add the exponents of 10.

scaffold.title: Review Block B: Functions & Linear Relationships (8.F, 8.EE)
scaffold.content: Quick-reference review of functions, slope, and systems.
keyPoints: Function: every input has exactly one output. Vertical line test.
Slope = rise/run = (y₂−y₁)/(x₂−x₁). THE most important 8th grade concept.
y = mx + b: m is rate of change, b is starting value (y-intercept).
Write equations from: slope + point, two points, graph, table.
Compare functions across representations: find slope and intercept for each.
Systems: intersection = solution. No solution = parallel. Infinite = same line.
Substitution: isolate one variable, plug into the other equation.

scaffold.title: Review Block B: Mixed Function & Linear Problems

problems.question: Function A: y = −x + 8. Function B goes through (0, 2) and (4, 10). Which has a greater rate of change? When do they have the same output?
problems.answer: A: slope = −1. B: slope = (10−2)/(4−0) = 2. B has greater rate of change (2 > −1). Equal: −x+8 = 2x+2 → 6 = 3x → x = 2. Both give y = 6.
hints: Find slope and equation for B first, then set them equal.

problems.question: Solve the system: 3x + y = 14 and x = y + 2
hints: The second equation already has x isolated — substitute directly.

problems.question: A table shows x: 1, 3, 5, 7 and y: 2, 8, 14, 20. Is this a linear function? If so, write the equation.
hints: Check that the rate of change is the same between all consecutive pairs.

scaffold.title: Review Block C: Geometry & Statistics (8.G, 8.SP)
scaffold.content: Quick-reference review of geometry and data analysis.
keyPoints: Transformations: translation (slide), reflection (flip), rotation (turn), dilation (scale).
Congruent = rigid motions only. Similar = rigid motions + dilation.
Parallel lines + transversal: corresponding=equal, alternate interior=equal, co-interior=supplementary.
Pythagorean theorem: a²+b²=c². Distance formula is Pythagorean in disguise.
Volume: cylinder πr²h, cone (1/3)πr²h, sphere (4/3)πr³. Scaling by k → volume ×k³.
Scatter plots: form, direction, strength. Line of best fit for predictions.
Correlation ≠ causation. Always look for lurking variables.

scaffold.title: Review Block C: Mixed Geometry & Stats Problems

problems.question: A right triangle has one leg of 9 and a hypotenuse of 15. Find the other leg.
hints: The hypotenuse is always c (the longest side). Rearrange a²+b²=c² to solve for the missing leg.

problems.question: A cylinder has radius 3 and height 10. A cone has radius 3 and height 10. What fraction of the cylinder's volume is the cone's volume?
problems.answer: Cylinder: π(9)(10) = 90π. Cone: (1/3)π(9)(10) = 30π. Fraction: 30π/90π = 1/3. (The cone is always 1/3 of the cylinder with same base and height.)

problems.question: A news article says 'States with more swimming pools have more car accidents.' Explain why swimming pools probably don't cause car accidents.
problems.answer: Lurking variable: population. States with more people have more of EVERYTHING — more pools, more cars, more accidents. Swimming pools don't cause car accidents; population size drives both.
hints: Think about what third variable could be related to BOTH swimming pools and car accidents.

examples.problem: A rectangle has length (2x+3) and width (x−1). The perimeter is 46. Find the dimensions and the length of the diagonal.

Two car rental companies: Company A charges $30/day + $0.15/mile. Company B charges $50/day + $0.05/mile. For a 1-day rental, (a) write a system, (b) find the break-even mileage, (c) which is cheaper for 300 miles?
A water tank is a cylinder with radius 5 ft and height 8 ft, topped with a hemisphere of radius 5 ft. Find the total volume.

scaffold.title: Error Analysis: Find and Fix Common Mistakes

examples.problem: Error analysis: A student wrote 3⁻² = −9. What's wrong?
examples.solution: 3⁻² means 1/3² = 1/9, NOT −9. A negative EXPONENT means reciprocal. A negative BASE would give a negative answer. −3² = −9 (negative of 3²), but 3⁻² = 1/9.

examples.problem: Error analysis: A student solved 2x−5 > 3 and got x > −1. What's wrong?
examples.solution: 2x > 8, so x > 4 (not −1). The student likely subtracted 5 instead of adding 5. 2x−5 > 3 → 2x > 3+5 = 8 → x > 4.

examples.problem: Error analysis: A student found the slope between (2,5) and (4,1) as m = (4−2)/(1−5) = 2/(−4) = −1/2. What's wrong?
examples.solution: The student switched x and y in the formula. Slope = (y₂−y₁)/(x₂−x₁) = (1−5)/(4−2) = −4/2 = −2, not −1/2. Remember: y-change goes on TOP.

examples.problem: Preview: Factoring. The expression x² + 5x + 6 can be written as (x+2)(x+3). Verify by expanding.
examples.solution: (x+2)(x+3) = x² + 3x + 2x + 6 = x² + 5x + 6 ✓. In Algebra 1, you'll learn to go BACKWARDS: from x²+5x+6 to (x+2)(x+3). This is called factoring.

examples.problem: Preview: Quadratic functions. The function y = x² is NOT linear — its graph is a parabola (U-shape). Compare: when x goes 1→2→3, y goes 1→4→9. Is the rate of change constant?
examples.solution: Rate of change: 1→4 is +3, 4→9 is +5. NOT constant! That's why the graph curves. In Algebra 1, you'll study these non-linear functions in depth.

examples.problem: Preview: Elimination. In 8th grade you solved systems by substitution. In Algebra 1, you'll learn elimination: add or subtract equations to cancel a variable. Example: x+y=7 and x−y=3 → add: 2x=10, x=5, y=2.
examples.solution: By adding the equations: (x+y)+(x−y) = 7+3 → 2x = 10 → x = 5. Then y = 7−5 = 2. Solution: (5, 2). Check: 5+2=7 ✓, 5−2=3 ✓. Much faster than substitution for some systems!

problems.question: Classify √49 and √50 as rational or irrational. Explain.
problems.answer: √49 = 7 → rational (it's a whole number = 7/1). √50 is irrational (50 is not a perfect square, so √50 is non-terminating, non-repeating).
hints: Check if the number under the square root is a perfect square.

problems.question: Solve: 7 − 2(x + 3) = 3x − 9
hints: Distribute −2 carefully (the negative matters!), then collect variables on one side.

problems.question: Write the equation of the line through (−2, 7) and (4, −5).
hints: Find slope first, then plug one point into y=mx+b to find b.

problems.question: A sphere has radius 9 cm. Find its volume in terms of π.
hints: V = (4/3)πr³. Don't forget to cube the radius.

problems.question: Solve the system: y = 4x − 1 and 2x + y = 11.
hints: y is already isolated in the first equation — substitute into the second.

problems.question: Find the distance between A(−3, 1) and B(5, −5). Then determine if triangle with vertices A(−3,1), B(5,−5), C(5,1) is a right triangle.
problems.answer: AB = √((5−(−3))²+(−5−1)²) = √(64+36) = √100 = 10. AC = 5−(−3) = 8 (horizontal). BC = |−5−1| = 6 (vertical). Check: 8²+6² = 64+36 = 100 = 10². Yes, right triangle (right angle at C).
hints: Find all three side lengths. If a²+b²=c², it's a right triangle.
